ratings.comment: She really knows her material, and can teach it very effectively. It is a hard class and you have to spend a lot of time to learn, but she is always there to support your learning. Solid choice 100%, can't go wrong with her.

She really knows her material, and can teach it very effectively. It is a hard class and you have to spend a lot of time to learn, but she is always there to support your learning. Solid choice, can't go wrong with her.

Andrea organizes her lecture really well. She knows exactly what concepts and difficult for students to understand and focuses on them multiple times in her lectures. Her lecture videos are amazing, a great help before the exam. Assignments are difficult and time consuming but they help you learn a lot.

The lecture wasn't very riveting, but they were helpful and the content necessary to learn was conveyed well. She also puts lectures online and the book is the BEST textbook I've ever had. HIGHLY recommend reading it. Projects weren't too bad, definitely get a project partner. This is a class I felt I learned something useful and interesting.

Andrea is a really nice lady who seems to care about students and is passionate about systems programming but the content is dry and power lectures can be hard to sit through. Luckily she uploads the lectures and the slides are grade. Her exams are fair but the projects are pretty time consuming but she curves for them
Nice lady but dry lectures. Often giggles and mumbles when speaking, uploads lec videos, which makes you less motivated to go to her lectures. Overall, a better than average professor.

Andrea teaches an incredible amount of material, and while her lectures can be dry, they move quickly and you'll learn a ton. She's also extremely helpful and caring in office hours and by email, and realizes that the class is challenging and will curve for it.

She cares about students, but boy this was a demanding class. I put in a lot of time for this class but wow was it rewarding, and the grading scale at the end was pretty curved. You learn a ton in this class and it's super interesting. Lectures could be hard to sit through. Time management and passion for the projects is key.

The course itself is too demanding ,when it comes to coding (debugging!!) the projects (total 10 sub-projects). The theory exams are relatively easier considering that slides and the free book are great. Grading criteria is quite clear  but she can make exceptions in initial projects.

Lectures can be a bit dry, making it hard to make it through the power lectures. Class was going through a restructuring, so organizationally things were all over the place at times. The free textbook is amazingly helpful, however. Plan to spend lots of time finding out where to put code in the xv6 portions of the homework.

She cares for students doing well and takes feedback in improving the presentation/organization of the class, which is great. Lectures are usually clear but there are times where she seems to speak with equivocation when explaining topics which made things confusing. Debugging programs can take an indeterminate amount of time, so start early.

the class at the beginning of the semester wasn't planned at all. projects were difficult and it was not easy2 tell where to look for the information we needed to complete them. sometimes the answer was right in a certain source, but with limited time it's impossible to read and understand 100% of the material we're give. little to no help w/ HWs

Andrea is a great professor. She really understands the material, and her textbook is extremely helpful (and free!). Programming projects are long and can be very difficult, but she often pushes back the deadlines. Exams are long, but fair. Lectures are well organized, but can be a bit quiet, especially in a large lecture hall.
